description: A nutritious egg laid by a bird.
A nutritious egg laid by a bird.  This one is unfertilized and probably from a farm.
A nutritious egg laid by a robin.  The shell is colored a distinctive light blue.

//: 5x the weight and 3x the nutrition of real chicken eggs, toxins equal to 296g mutant meat

description: A large, heavy ant egg, the size of a softball.  Extremely nutritious, but incredibly gross.
A large, heavy acid ant egg, the size of a softball.  Extremely nutritious, but incredibly gross.
A fist-sized egg from a giant roach.  Incredibly gross.
A fist-sized egg from a plague vector.  Incredibly gross.
A fist-sized egg from a locust.
The still-wet egg of a mutated dragonfly.  Serves as a disgusting substitute for the real thing, just don't let it hatch in the water.
The fist-sized egg of a mutant firefly.  Glows faintly in the dark.
A large, soft egg of a mutant centipede.  Inside, you can already see a bundle of spindly legs, twitching in anticipation.
A white, flexible wasp egg.  It looks like a pristine grain of rice the size of your palm.
A huge, translucent beetle egg.  You can see a larva slowly squirming inside, contorting uncomfortably outside of the soil.
A large, white antlion egg.  There is something hard inside.
A large, sticky, and wet water strider egg.  You should probably put it back in the water.
A long, white, pill-shaped grasshopper egg.  Inside you can see two twitching legs.
A ladybug egg.  It looks like a huge yellow rice grain.  You can see a translucent, hungry larva inside.
A mole cricket egg covered in bits of sand and dirt.  It's brown with a few black dots on it.
Praying mantis eggs glued to each other inside a strange-looking case.  It resembles a trilobite or a woodlouse.
The egg of a fly.
The egg of a moth fly.
The egg of a silverfish.
The egg of a house centipede.
The egg of a mosquito.
The egg of a cellar spider.
The egg of a jumping spider.
The egg of a trapdoor spider.
The egg of a web spider.
The egg of a black widow.
The egg of a wolf spider.
The egg of an earthworm.
The egg of a slug.
The egg of a snail.
A clump of razorclaw eggs.  A post-Cataclysm delicacy.
Common roe from an unknown fish.

//: Gar eggs are poisonous - this is not an oversight. This is also why these are omitted from the cooking requirement group.

description: A large half-translucent glob with a mutant fish fry inside.
Whole fresh eggs, dehydrated into an easy to store powder.
Rehydrated eggs.  You can use them instead of eggs when cooking, provided you don't care that they have lost their complete shape.
Fluffy and delicious scrambled eggs.
Tasty scrambled eggs, with seasoning to taste!
A hard-boiled egg, still in its shell.  Portable and nutritious!
Hard-boiled eggs, mixed into a salad.  Can be made into a sandwich!
Sunny-side up eggs fried with a runny yolk and just a bit of crisp on the edges.
A tasty fried egg, with seasoning added to taste!
Deluxe sunny-side up eggs fried with a runny yolk and just a bit of crisp on the edges with cheese or a vegetable, garnish and condiment.
Sunny-side up eggs fried with a runny yolk and just a bit of crisp on the edges.  Made into a sandwich, just like Sunday morning.
Deluxe sunny-side up eggs fried with a runny yolk and just a bit of crisp on the edges.  Made into a sandwich, just like Sunday morning.
A fluffy beaten egg pancaked over with cheese inside.
A fluffy beaten egg pancaked over with cheese and vegetables inside.
A fluffy beaten egg pancaked over with cheese, vegetables, and meat all stuffed inside.  The mother of all omelets.
A simple sandwich with sliced, hard boiled eggs and mayo to balance out the saltiness of the caviar.  Scandinavian breakfast staple.
A pickled egg.  Rather salty, but tastes good and lasts for a long time.

Roe in the process of becoming fully cured with salt, capable of becoming homemade caviar.  The flavor is slowly developing at this stage, and is currently significantly unpleasant due to the residual salt.  Activate it once completed to make use of the final product.

use_action.msg: You remove the roe from the brine and now have post apocalypse caviar.
use_action.not_ready_msg: The roe isn't fully cured yet.

description: Fish eggs that have been cured in a salty brine.  Can be vacuum sealed to preserve freshness.  Technically caviar only came from a specific type of Sturgeon roe but the FDA allows all cured fish to be referred to as caviar.

//: Volume and calories defined manually because proportional rounded them down to 0

name: water beetle egg
description: The egg of a water beetle, usually found near aquatic grass.

name: water scorpion egg
description: The egg of a water scorpion, usually found near aquatic grass.

name: butterfly egg
description: The egg of a butterfly.  They are usually found clustered on leaves.

name: moth egg
description: The egg of a moth.  They are usually found clustered on leaves.

name: cicada egg
description: The egg of a cicada.  They are usually found near trees.
A popular traditional Turkish dish which includes eggs, tomato, green peppers, and spices such as ground black and red pepper cooked in olive oil.
A large clump of frog eggs.  They're gelatinous and transparent.
This is a dense cluster of dark frog's eggs, not dissimilar in appearance to caviar.
A thin film of frog eggs floats together atop the water in a roughly circular mass.
These eggs float in long strands, drifting in the still water.
A spiral strand of frog eggs adorns a patch of underwater vegetation.
A loose grouping of surprisingly few frog's eggs, anchored to submerged vegetation.
A small patch of frog's eggs rests on the water's surface.
A tight, spherical cluster of eggs, often found near submerged vegetation.  This cluster is polar, with dark pigment collected near the tops of the eggs and white left on the underside.
A globular mass of frog's eggs.  The individual eggs are colored a dark brown on top and a yellow-cream on the bottom.
A thin sheet of clear, gelatinous eggs with dark embryos peppered throughout.
This softball-sized mass of gooey eggs clings together like a bunch of soft, transparent grapes.  The "seeds" inside these appear to be growing legs.
Several short strands of tightly clustered black eggs connected together by their viscous coverings.
A large clump of very large frog eggs.  They're gelatinous, transparent and larger than even chicken's eggs.
From a distance you could mistake it for a cluster of gigantic caviar.  It is only on close inspection that you can make out the faint translucence of these softball-sized frog eggs.
A thick flotilla of enormous frog eggs floats together atop the water in a roughly circular mass.
Looking like a submerged buoy-line, this long strand of softball-sized, gelatinous eggs floats gently in the still water.
This is a spiral strand of giant frog eggs.  Its increased weight and size nearly smothers the submerged vegetation it clings to.
A patch of giant frog's eggs resembling a very thick, clear sack of oranges.
These golfball-sized frog eggs cling together by their sticky membranes.
